Literature Review: Cell-cell communication is a fundamental process in multicellular organisms, essential for development, homeostasis, and various physiological functions. Traditionally, the focus has been on trans interactions between receptors on one cell and ligands on neighboring cells. However, recent research has shed light on the importance of cis interactions between receptors and ligands expressed on the same cell surface, particularly in immune cell functions.Trans interactions have long been recognized as the primary mechanism for cell-cell communication. These interactions involve receptors on one cell binding to ligands on adjacent cells, triggering signaling cascades that lead to cellular responses. This paradigm has been well-established in various biological systems, including the nervous and immune systems. For instance, Dustin and Baldari (2017) reviewed the role of trans interactions in T cell activation, highlighting the importance of antigen recognition and costimulatory signals in initiating immune responses.While trans interactions remain crucial, the significance of cis interactions has emerged as an important regulatory mechanism in cell biology. Cis interactions occur when receptors and ligands are co-expressed on the same cell surface and interact with each other. These interactions can have profound effects on cellular functions, often by modulating the availability or activity of receptors and ligands for trans interactions.In the context of immune cell functions, cis interactions have been shown to play critical roles in regulating various aspects of immune responses. One well-studied example is the interaction between major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules and CD8 coreceptors on T cells. Artyomov et al. (2010) demonstrated that cis interactions between MHC class I molecules and CD8 on the same T cell surface can enhance the sensitivity and specificity of T cell responses to antigens presented by other cells in trans.Another important example of cis interactions in immune cells involves the CD22 receptor on B cells. Müller et al. (2013) showed that CD22 can bind to sialic acid-containing glycoproteins on the same B cell surface, creating a network of cis interactions that regulate B cell activation thresholds. These cis interactions help maintain B cell tolerance and prevent inappropriate activation in response to self-antigens.The importance of cis interactions extends beyond lymphocytes to other immune cell types. For instance, Barkal et al. (2018) discovered that the "don't eat me" signal CD47 can engage in cis interactions with signal regulatory protein α (SIRPα) on macrophages, influencing their phagocytic activity. This finding has implications for cancer immunotherapy, as disrupting these cis interactions could potentially enhance the ability of macrophages to eliminate tumor cells.Cis interactions can also modulate the function of cytokine receptors. Zenatti et al. (2011) reported that cis interactions between the IL-7 receptor α chain (IL-7Rα) and the common γ chain (γc) on T cells can regulate IL-7 signaling, which is crucial for T cell development and homeostasis. These cis interactions may fine-tune the sensitivity of T cells to IL-7 and contribute to the maintenance of the T cell pool.The regulatory effects of cis interactions are not limited to immune cells. In the nervous system, Yin et al. (2018) demonstrated that cis interactions between ephrin ligands and Eph receptors on the same neuron can modulate axon guidance and targeting. This finding highlights the broader significance of cis interactions in cellular communication across different biological systems.Despite the growing recognition of the importance of cis interactions, many questions remain unanswered. One key area of investigation is the molecular mechanisms underlying the formation and regulation of cis complexes. Structural studies, such as those conducted by Xu et al. (2013) on the cis interaction between PD-1 and its ligands, are providing insights into the molecular basis of these interactions. However, more research is needed to understand how these interactions are dynamically regulated in different cellular contexts.Another important question is how cis and trans interactions are integrated to fine-tune cellular responses. Carlin et al. (2018) proposed a model in which cis interactions can create inhibitory microclusters that regulate the formation of activating synapses between immune cells. This concept suggests a complex interplay between cis and trans interactions in shaping immune cell functions.Furthermore, the potential therapeutic implications of modulating cis interactions are an exciting area of research. As demonstrated by the work of Barkal et al. (2018) on CD47-SIRPα interactions, targeting cis complexes could offer new strategies for immunotherapy and other therapeutic approaches.In conclusion, while trans interactions remain a cornerstone of cell-cell communication, the importance of cis interactions between membrane receptors and ligands is becoming increasingly apparent, particularly in immune cell functions. These cis interactions represent a fundamental regulatory mechanism in cell biology, offering new insights into cellular communication and potential therapeutic targets. Future research will undoubtedly reveal more about the complexities of cis interactions and their roles in various biological processes.
